quiz.title: Slope as Rate of Change
quiz.subtitle: Unit 4.2: Interpreting Slope in Real-World Contexts
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Real-World Applications of Slope, Rate Interpretation

questions.question: A car travels 150 miles in 3 hours. What is the rate of change of distance with respect to time?
The graph shows a tank filling with water. What does the slope represent?
options: Filling rate in gallons per minute
questions.explanation: On a volume vs. time graph, slope = $\frac{\Delta \text{volume}}{\Delta \text{time}}$ = filling rate.

questions.question: A phone battery drains from 100% to 40% in 2 hours. What is the rate of battery drain?
questions.explanation: Rate = $\frac{40 - 100}{2} = \frac{-60}{2} = -30$% per hour (or draining at 30% per hour).

questions.question: A company's profits increased from \$20,000 to \$35,000 over 5 years. What is the average annual rate of change?
The temperature drops from 75°F to 55°F over 4 hours. What is the rate of temperature change?
What does a slope of 0.25 represent in a cost vs. weight graph for apples?
A candle's height decreases from 12 inches to 8 inches over 10 hours. What is the burning rate?
The graph shows a runner's distance over time. What does a steeper slope indicate?
questions.explanation: On distance-time graphs, steeper slope = greater distance per time = faster speed.

questions.question: A savings account grows from \$500 to \$650 in 2 years. What is the annual growth rate?
What does a negative slope represent in an elevation vs. distance hiked graph?
questions.explanation: Negative slope = elevation decreases as distance increases = descending.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent rate interpretation! You can translate slope into real-world rates across diverse contexts.
scoreMessages.70: Strong application skills! Review units and sign interpretation (negative rates = decrease).
scoreMessages.50: Good start. Practice: 1) Setting up $\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}$, 2) Including units, 3) Interpreting positive/negative.
scoreMessages.0: Begin with simple rates: distance/time = speed. Practice calculating and interpreting with clear units.
